history.content: Approach faculty directly, via emails or office hours. Make the email specific to them and their research. Be persistent and try multiple people. Explain your past CS background, even if it does not fulfill requirements here. Review https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/research. Attend the two undergraduate research panels coming this fall for more information.

To add to the staff answers it's really important that you are very persistent and develop a thick skin. When I was looking for research I initially contacted about 20 professors and grad students/postdocs and I didn't just spam, I tailor made each email and for almost all of them read through and talked about at least one paper that the person I was writing to had authored. I was also a relatively well qualified candidate. I only got 3 responses, 2 were negative and one was a lead that eventually resulted in the position I have now, I received nothing from the rest. I'm publishing in my current position and have loved the experience so good things do happen. The harsh reality of the situation is that there are way more students who want research than there are positions, just look at your classes sizes and see how many professors are teaching those classes (the joys of going to an overcrowded school in an even more overcrowded major). You should also apply to URAP (http://urap.berkeley.edu) but again be aware that the numbers are really tight there too. Even if you haven't taken upper-divs do your best to cultivate some knowledge on subjects you want to research and sell what knowledge you do have, there will likely be professors who would want to put you to work with your current knowledge. In reality what is likely to happen is that you will need to learn a bunch of stuff for your research that isn't taught in classes anyway since research tends to be much more narrow in focus than our classes are. Make sure you demonstrate that you are motivated to learn and work because those are the most important things for research.

I don't bring up the numbers and my personal experience to scare you, I do so because I hope it will help you understand that experiencing a very high rate of rejection is totally normal, don't be discouraged by it and please don't give up because it's worth it in the end. Keep contacting professors and you will get a position; I haven't met someone who kept trying and didn't get a position but I know a few people who gave up after an initial rough set of responses (or rather lack of responses at all). Just know a lot of profs won't respond and a lot won't have positions available, just don't let that get to you. That doesn't reflect anything about you, that is just the way the numbers work out. You might get lucky too, one of my friends who is similarly qualified to me sent out way fewer emails than I did and got more offers. Keep at it and you will get something.

As an incoming junior transfer, none of my past CS courses transfer. I'm interested in doing research, even if its just grunt work, but it seems like many opportunities require core or upper division knowledge which I will not be able to obtain until next year. I'd really like to apply to grad school but I feel like I won't be able to get the research experience in time. Any advice would be helpful.
history.subject: How can I get research experience as an incoming fall transfer?
